summary: apoD, a 29 kDa glycoprotein, is a member of the lipocalin super family. it transports several small hydrophobic compounds such as arachidonic acid (AA), progesterone, pregnenolone, bilirubin, cholesterol and E-3-methyl-2-hexenoic acid. in human, apoD is found in the plasma fraction, associated with high-density lipoprotein (HDL) it is highly expressed in PPAR regulates positively its own transcription and induces transcription of the CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein (C/EBP), which in turn activates PPAR gene expression. many natural PPAR ligands have been discovered including AA, prostaglandins, oxidized fatty acid (FA) and some polyunsaturated fatty acid (PUFA) lipoatrophic mice develop hepatic steatosis through over-expression. inhibition of PPAR expression reduces hepatic steatosis. lipogenesis is regulated at various levels.
